content.value: Air pollution is the world’s leading environmental health risk and a major cause of environmental degradation. Atmospheric pollutants from energy transformation and consumption, and from industrial processes, are the main contributors to regional and local air pollution. Major concerns relate to their effects on human health and ecosystems. Human exposure is particularly high in urban areas where economic activities are concentrated and where demand for mobility is highest. Poor air quality can have substantial economic and social consequences, from health costs and a lower quality of life to infrastructure maintenance, reduced agricultural output and forest damage. Some population groups are especially vulnerable to air pollution. The very young and the very old are the most at risk.
is a local air pollutant that seriously affects human health. Chronic exposure even to moderate levels of PM

substantially increases the risk of heart disease and stroke. It is an important cause of death in LAC countries (GBD, 2019). It also increases the risk of respiratory diseases, including lung cancer, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, and respiratory infections. Black carbon, a major component of PM
, accelerates global warming and fosters snowmelt.
The main challenges are to further reduce
emissions of local and regional air pollutants,
to achieve a strong decoupling of emissions
from economic growth and limit people’s
exposure to polluted air. This implies
and control policies and sustainable transport

Emissions can be reduced by substituting dirty fuels for cleaner ones, focusing development on cleaner industries, reducing consumption of polluting products and adopting cleaner technologies. Behavioural and lifestyle changes are also important.

Policies that provide incentives across a broad spectrum of firms and consumers (e.g. emission or energy taxes) tend to be more cost-efficient than those that target a specific product, fuel or technology (e.g. subsidies for electric cars).

Both the sources of air pollution and severity of exposure vary across and within countries. Hence it is important to tailor policies to specific local circumstances. For example, more stringent measures are required in densely populated areas or for emission sources located upwind from urban areas. Such spatially heterogeneous policies help achieve environmental objectives at lower costs than measures that apply uniformly to sources in all locations and to populations at all risk levels.

Environmental performance can be assessed against domestic objectives and international commitments. Reducing negative impacts of degraded air quality is part of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development (New York, September 2015) under
“Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages” and under
“Make cities and human settlements inclusive, safe, resilient and sustainable”

Progress can be assessed by measuring the evolution of emissions, the exposure of population to air pollutants, the related health effects and their costs, and the evolution of policy stringency directed at pricing air pollution. The costs of air pollution mainly arise from its detrimental impact on human health. These take the form of shorter life expectancy, increased healthcare costs and reduced labour productivity. Further consequences include reduced agricultural output and damage to ecosystems and built structures.
The indicators presented here focus on xxxx. They show population exposure to fine particulates ….

Transport, 126 million registered vehicles in 2015, including passenger transport vehicles and commercial vehicles, with the countries with the highest numbers being Brazil, Mexico, Argentina, Colombia, Venezuela, Puerto Rico and Peru. Source: OICA / International Organization of Motor Vehicle Manufacturers / International Organization of Motor Vehicle Manufacturers (OICA), Number of vehicles in use 2015 – worldwide

Motorisation rate (number of vehicles per thousand inhabitants) reached 900 in 2015 for the region, with the countries with the highest rates being Barbados (387), Suriname (349), Bahamas (336), Argentina (317) and Mexico (300).

Agriculture: The region contains around 650 million hectares of agricultural area, of which Brazil counts with the largest area, with close to 250 million hectares, followed by Argentina, Mexico, Colombia, Bolivia, Peru, Venezuela and Uruguay. Countries with high proportions of land under organic agriculture relative to the region include Uruguay (19.5% in 2020), French Guiana (11.3%), Dominican Republic (4.8%) and Argentina (4.1%).
Value added from agriculture sector, as a proportion of GDP:
7% is the average of the LAC region.
Urbanisation: share of built-up/artificial areas, rate of increase, conversion from natural areas to agriculture

The region’s population increasingly lives in urban as opposed to rural areas, reaching 81.2% in 2020. Countries such as Chile, Argentina, Venezuela, Uruguay, Brazil, Mexico and Peru are amongst the highest in the region to have a predominantly urban population.

The population is predominantly urban across all three sub-regions, where South America has the highest proportion with 85% of the population living in urban areas, followed by Central and North America, with 75%, and the Caribbean, with 67% of the population.

The Caribbean is the sub-region with the highest population density having 1.87 persons per hectare in 2021, followed by Central and North America with 0.73 persons per hectare, and South America with 0.24 persons per hectare. Very sparse density, but concentrated around big cities such as São Paulo, Bogotá, Lima, Rio de Janeiro and Buenos Aires.
Air pollution is linked to respiratory infections, including pneumonia, cardiovascular disease, including ischemic heart disease and stroke, cancer and chronic respiratory diseases.

In the LAC region, age-standardised deaths attributable to pollution is relatively low as compared to Sub-Saharan Africa, South Asia, East Asia and the Pacific. However, deaths by air pollution remains a significant issue, with the rate of attributable deaths being higher than in North America, Europe and Central Asia, and Middle East and North Africa. Within the region, Haiti has been the country of the region with the highest proportion of attributable deaths to air pollution over the past three decades, with 201 per a hundred thousand deaths in 2019. Haiti is followed by Honduras, Guatemala, Guyana, Bolivia, Nicaragua, Suriname and the Dominican Republic.

Each sub-region presents variations in the leading air pollutant to cause these deaths. Ambient ozone pollution is most deadly in Mexico, Honduras, Bolivia, Haiti and Brazil. The pollutant PM2.5 has the highest incidence in Guyana, followed by Caribbean countries such as Grenada, Trinidad and Tobago, and Saint Vincent and the Grenadines. When it comes to household air pollution from solid fuels, Haiti has the highest incidence of attributable deaths, followed by Central American countries such as Honduras, Guatemala and Nicaragua.

In 2019, chronic respiratory diseases caused over 180,000 deaths in the LAC region, most of which were due to chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. Brazil has the highest number of deaths related to chronic respiratory diseases in absolute terms, with 77,700 in 2019, followed by Mexico, Colombia, Venezuela, Peru, Cuba, Ecuador and Bolivia. South America contains the largest number of deaths in absolute terms, followed by Central and North America, and the Caribbean.

The Disability-Adjusted Life Years (DALYs) in the region are seriously affected by chronic respiratory diseases, with South America suffering from over 3 million DALYs in 2019, followed by 1.25 million in Central and North America, and 430 thousand in the Caribbean.

content.value: International data on particulate emissions are available for many but not all LAC countries. The estimation methods for emissions, the extent of sources and particles included in estimation, may differ from one country to another.

Exposure indicators provide only a partial view of air pollution severity and consequences aggregated across the entire population. Importantly, there is generally no “safe level” of exposure for many pollutants. Even where guideline or target exposures are met, substantial public health and economic benefits can be realised through further improvements in air quality. Better estimates are needed for exposure to both outdoor and indoor air pollution. Particular attention should be paid to exposure of sensitive groups and quantitative impact on human health (and associated distributional and equity issues). Although many important gaps remain, available data are improving.

pagesInfo.title: Climate change adaptation - Impacts and risks

toc.value: Environment at a Glance Indicators: Latin America and Caribbean (LAC) provides interactive on-line access to the latest comparable LAC-country data on the environment. The tool helps users evaluate environmental performance in the region’s countries and track their course towards sustainable development. This web version allows users to play with the data, dive into the analysis and download the webbook. The indicators provide key messages on major environmental trends in areas such as climate change, biodiversity, and selected policy responses to these issues. They will be progressively extended to cover other areas such as water resources, air quality, circular economy, and ocean resources as more information becomes available.
